title-group.article-title: Effect of titanium-dioxide nanoparticle on Richardson constant and barrier height of tartrazine dye based Schottky device

institution-wrap.institution: Department of Physics, Condensed Matter Physics Research Center

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Recently Fruit Dyes have achieved a significant interest as organic devices because of they are widely available, customizable and biodegradable. But low conductivity is one of the major limitations. Low conductivity is due to low charge injection from the electrodes to the organic layer and the charge injection process is strongly dependent on the injection barrier height at the metal-dye interface. Higher barrier height causes low charge injection. A detailed analysis is needed to reduce the interfacial barrier to get better conductivity. In this work, we have estimated the interfacial barrier height of Indium tin oxide coated glass/Tartrazine dye/Copper based device with and without titanium dioxide nanoparticles. The devices have been prepared with dye and dye-nanoparticles blends by using the spin coating technique. We have measured the steady state dark current–voltage–temperature characteristics in the range of 288 K to 333 K to estimate the Richardson constant and interfacial barrier height. The Richardson constant was found to be modified from 44.35 × 10–3 to 07.34 × 10–3 Am−2 K−2. We also have found that interfacial barrier height is reduced from 0.71 eV to 0.64 eV in the presence of nanoparticles at room temperature. As the temperature increased, the interfacial barrier height increased to 0.72 eV from 0.71 eV and to 0.68 eV from 0.62 eV for dye based device with and without nanoparticles, respectively. Reduction of the interfacial barrier height indicates an increase in the charge injection through the interface. This work will be informative to improve the charge flow at the metal–fruit dye interface.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The current conduction mechanism through the metal-natural organic dye junction is frequently described as the thermionic emission process in Schottky contacts [1–4]. However, the natural organic dye based devices are most effectively constrained by the limited current flow through these junctions. The link between the Schottky Barrier Height (SBH) and temperature has a significant impact on the thermal stability of the majority of organic or natural organic dye based electrical and photo-electronic systems. Because the SBH of a junction completely controls the current flow to electronic and photoelectric devices based connections [5]. The SBH for various metal–organic connections must therefore be evaluated. To determine the barrier height of the junction with the saturation current the Schottky thermionic emission theory is a popular recommendation [6]. A key characteristic of the thermionic emission process in Schottky junctions is the Richardson constant (A*) [7]. In a perfect Schottky diode, the emission of carriers from the semiconductor over a spatially homogenous barrier into the [7]. The theoretical value is typically taken to be the value of the effective Richardson constant for most of the published papers. Knowing the true value of A* for these junctions is important in order to evaluate the current–voltage (I–V) response appropriately. Some previously published articles shows that the A* values may vary according to the material used to build the junction [8–10].

Now, different nanoparticles can be mixed with natural organic colours and polymers to enhance the charge flow at the interface [11–14]. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanoparticles (NPs) is an inexpensive, high-temperature stable, n-type wide band gap semiconductor material. Three polymorphs of TiO2 can form during crystallisation: rutile, anatase, and brookite. Only under a narrow range of growth circumstances can anatase, a metastable phase, be produced. Rutile phase is the most prevalent and thermodynamically stable phase, whereas the synthesis of brookite can only be done under extremely harsh conditions [15, 16]. TiO2 has been used in some earlier works to increase the efficiency of sandwiched organic devices by improving the morphology of the active layers. Due to its chemical stability and biocompatibility, TiO2 is also used in gas sensors, photocatalytic degradation of organic compounds, and photovoltaic and photo electrochemical cells [17–19]. These devices can have better light absorption, charge separation, and charge collecting by including such NPs. But the effect of NPs on the barrier properties especially the Richardson constant is not known. But it is very important to estimate the value of Richardson constant in presence of NPs for further studies.

In this work, we investigated the impact of titanium dioxide (TiO2) NPs on the Schottky device based on Tartrazine (TZ) dye's Richardson constant. This work enables us to quantify the various electrical characteristics precisely in the presence of TiO2 NPs and will aid in our understanding of how TiO2 affects the SBH value of devices based on natural organic dyes. In our earlier study, we calculated the Schottky device format Richardson constant for TZ dye [20]. We have employed the Schottky diode construction, with a copper plate (Cu) serving as the back electrode and an Indium-Tin-oxide coated glass (ITO) serving as the front electrode. Between the two eletrodes was a 1:1 mixture of dye and nanoparticles. Using a Keithley-2400 source metre and a temperature range of 288 K to 333 K (30 °C to 60 °C), the relationship between current (I) and voltage (V) is measured.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
As we have stated in our previously published papers, TZ is a synthetic lemon yellow azo dye primarily used as a food coloring [20–22]. It is also known as E-number E102, C.I. 19,140, FD&C Yellow 5, Yellow 5 Lake, Acid Yellow 23, Food Yellow 4, and trisodium 1-(4-sulfonatophenyl)-4-(4-sulfonatophenylazo)-5-pyrazolone-3-carboxylate) [23]. Figure 1 depicts the chemical structure of TZ dye.Fig.1
Chemical structure Tartrazine

Chemical formula of the TZ dye is C16H9N4Na3O9S2. It's an azo dye with a chromophoric azo group ‘–N = N–’, which has nitrogen atoms coupled to SP2-hybridized carbon atoms [24]. At least one of these carbon atoms is from an aromatic carbocycle or heterocycle, whereas the second carbon atom next to the azo group could be from an enolizable aliphatic derivative [25].

sec.title: Cell preparation
sec.p: In our earlier published articles we have discussed the cell preparation procedure which is consists of three sequential steps [10, 20, 26]. The cleaning of the electrodes is the first stage. Cu plates and glass with ITO coatings are first swabbed with a mild detergent. Rinse under DI water after 10 min of soaking in the detergent at 60 °C. The electrodes are then sonicated for 10 min with DI water, 2-propanol, and acetone before being placed in a nitrogen atmosphere to dry. Prior to spin coating, we subjected the sample to UV ozone treatment for 10 min and heated it for 3 h to 200 °C.

The process of sample solution preparation is the second step. 30 ml of deionized water and one gram of PVA, as determined by Dhona-100DS, are combined to make the 30% PVA solution, which is then stirred with a magnetic stirrer for an hour while 313 K is added. In this situation, PVA functions as an inert binder [25]. Using the Dhona-100DS to weigh the 2 mg of TZ dye and TiO2 NPs, we separately dissolved each substance in 1 ml of previously prepared 30% PVA solution using a magnetic stirrer for 48 h. Next, we used a hot air oven to dry and annelled both samples at 80 °C for 24 h. After being completely grind, the samples were kept in a vacuum dessicator.

The third step involves creating the sandwiched structure device. 0.5 mg of the generated dye was mixed with 1 and 2 ml of DMF solvent in two separate beakers for 30 min using an ultrasonic sonicator. After 3 more minutes at ambient temperature, the created TiO2 was mixed with the 2 ml of solvent in the beaker using an ultrasonic sonicator. On previously cleaned ITO glass slides that have been semi-dried in a vacuum with the aid of a desiccator, we spin coat the prepared samples separately using an APEX spin coater at 1500 rpm. After that, we attach the Cu plate as a back electrode to the sample to construct a Metal-Dye-Metal (MDM) structure. These devices are then maintained for 12 h in a vacuum and in a dark environment before being characterized and allowed to dry. Figure 2a provides the schematic diagram of the cell. Figure 2b and c represents the thin film cross-sectional view of dye and dye incorporated with nanoparticles. The average thickness has been found to be 459.4 nm for dye and 814.5 nm for dye incorporated with NPs.Fig.2
a Schematic cell diagram of ITO/Dye/Cu cell. b SEM image for the thickness of TZ dye thin film. c SEM image for the thickness of TZ dye with TiO2 nanoparticles thin film

sec.title: Measurement
sec.p:
The dark IVT characteristics of the cells have been measured using a Keithley 2400 source unit and the temperature varies and measured from 303 to 333 K simultaneously with a Regulated Heat Source unit. During measurement, the bias voltage is varied from 0 to 5 V in steps of 0.5 V with 1500 ms delay. The simple circuit diagram of our experiment is given in Fig. 3. The experiments have been done in a dust-free space using a glove box with a dark atmosphere.Fig.3
Schematic circuit diagram of temperature-dependent I–V–T characteristics

sec.title: Result
sec.p:
The Richardson Constant of several fruit dyes, including the TZ dye, was revealed in our previously published study [10, 20]. Ae may see that the Richardson Constant values for various materials vary. Figure 4 illustrates the I–V–T features of the produced cells. Figure 4a depicts the I–V–T plot of a dye alone, while Fig. 4b depicts a dye-TiO2 mixture. We can see from the graphs that the conduction current rises as the temperature rises and TiO2 is added. The total area that contributes to the current transport in inhomogeneous Schottky-barrier diodes (SBD) is temperature and bias dependent, and the carrier conduction process in forward bias is dominated by the emission of carriers from the semiconductor over a spatially homogeneous barrier into the metal, which is also enhanced with the incorporation of nanoparticle.Fig.4
Schematic circuit diagram of temperature-dependent I–V–T characteristics of a TZ Dye without TiO2 nanoparticles, b TZ dye with TiO2 nanoparticles

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study used a spin-coating method to construct an ITO/Dye/Cu structure with and without TiO2 nanopartocles. Under no light conditions, the current–voltage–temperature (I–V–T) properties of both devices were investigated. We can observe that the use of nanoparticles modifies the Richardson constant, changing the barrier height. The zero bias barrier height has a nonlinear relationship with temperature, which suggests that the barrier height is not uniform. The charge injection through the metal–organic interlayer is impacted by the inhomogeneous distribution. The nonlinearity of the barrier height is enhanced by the introduction of TiO2 nanoparticles. The alteration of the barrier’s inhomogeneity at the interface may be responsible for this result. As a result, the barrier height is lowered, there is a higher charge injection, and thus, there is a higher conduction current. For a detailed investigation of the barrier height modification for devices based on synthetic or natural organic dyes, thin work will be helpful.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: I sincerely express my gratitude to all my friends of our lab to encourage and help me to do this work.

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: All data generated or analyzed during this study are included in this article.

sec.title: Competing interests
sec.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
